results.title: Addressing low rates in insurance offerings
results.topLine: 360 insurance company executives in 25 different global markets respond to our question about low interest rates. Read more.

cards.takeaway:
As part of our ongoing series based on the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report, 360 senior insurance company executives across 25 markets have shared their experiences and forecasts regarding the global insurance landscape with BlackRock. 

Here's how they answered the question: How are you responding to the effect of low interest rates in the unit-linked side of the business? The following is how their answers break down.

cards.description: of insurers who responded said they are trying to grow the unit-linked side of the business.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.description: of survey respondents said they have no intention of changing their current business models.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.description: responded that they are shrinking investments in the unit-linked part of their businesses.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.description: of insurers who responded to our survey said low interest rates were not applicable to their businesses.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Group Chief Investment Officer, AIA
cards.quote: In Asia, investment-linked products (ILPs) have to contend with long-term saversâ€™ apparent preference for complementing cash deposits with high-risk opportunities. The availability of contracts with investment guarantees has further limited the growth of ILPs.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Group Chief Investment Officer, AIA
cards.quote: Changing capital regimes and lower interest rates are now likely to undermine the viability of those guarantees, setting the stage for ILP expansion, particularly if more savings migrate from low interest paying bank accounts.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.takeaway: Life and multiline insurers appear broadly comfortable with their unit-linked business, with nearly one in three looking to grow. Low rates and changing capital regimes may lead to long-term changes in many Asian markets, as highlighted by Mark Konyn of AIA.

results.title: Challenges of working from home in insurance
results.topLine: 360 insurance executives in 25 different global markets respond to our questions about the challenges of working from home.

cards.takeaway:
As part of our ongoing series based on the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report, 360 senior insurance company executives across 25 markets have shared their experiences and forecasts regarding the global insurance landscape with BlackRock. 

Here's how they responded to the question: What challenges has a work from home environment brought to your investment team? What follows is the response.

BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.
Respondents selected up to three responses.

cards.headline: Technology enables remote employees
cards.body: As with most other sectors, the pandemic has led to insurance activities being conducted remotely with most staff working from home. Surprisingly, only 24% reported technology gaps. For large insurers this was even less of an issue (16%). The main concerns centered instead on risk management and the ability to maintain a culture of innovation and idea generation.

cards.title: CIO of FM Global
cards.quote: To our surprise, we have seen a further rise in our already high productivity, but as time goes by, we are rather concerned about some decay of interpersonal collaboration, innovation and collective creativity.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.takeaway: Technology gaps do not appear to be a big concern in a work from home environment for the various investment teams we surveyed. Insurers did, however, express some concerns about cyber security. Employee well-being is another area of focus.

results.title: Geopolitics: A fragmented world
results.topLine: The pandemic has added fuel to geopolitical dynamics already underway.

cards.takeaway: The pandemic has added fuel to geopolitical dynamics already underway. The post coronavirus world is likely to be characterized by four key themes.

cards.label: Increasing bifurcation
cards.description: First, the world is increasingly becoming bifurcated, with the U.S. and China at opposite poles. Intense rivalry looks set to affect nearly every dimension of the U.S. China relationship regardless of the U.S. election outcome.

cards.body:
Other countries will increasingly be pushed to choose sides. Decoupling is focused on
but not limited to the technology sector. This means investors need exposure to both markets, especially as the center of gravity of global growth is moving to Asia, as the following chart shows.

cards.title: Shifting center of gravity
cards.subtitle: Regional share of global GDP, 1990 2024
cards.source: BlackRock Investment Institute, with data from IMF, Refinitiv ., June 2020. Notes: The lines show how each regionâ€™s combined share of global GDP on a purchasing power parity basis. The dotted lines show the forecast period based on IMF projections to 2024.

cards.label: Less globalization
cards.description: Second, the pandemic is poised to accelerate deglobalization as it magnifies nationalist and protectionist trends. The crisis adds to existing pressures such as global trade tensions and populism. This threatens to disrupt the web of global supply chains at the expense of efficiency. It may lead to onshoring the production of strategic goods.

cards.label: Policy intervention
cards.description: Third, government intervention in economies is likely to become more entrenched. Unprecedented policy support comes with strings attached including curbs on share buybacks and dividend payouts and companies increasingly will need a social license to operate.

cards.label: Exacerbated inequality
cards.description: Lastly, the pandemic exacerbates inequalities within and across countries. It has hit hard emerging economies with more limited institutional capacity.

cards.title: Chairman, BlackRock Investment Institute
cards.quote: We face a far less globalized international system, with states playing a greater role in the private economy.

cards.body: Domestic polarization is on the rise too, with the U.S. presidential election set to take place against the most tumultuous domestic backdrop since 1968. The two parties are as far apart on policy as they have ever been, making the result consequential for markets.

cards.takeaway: The world looks increasingly bifurcated, with the U.S. and China at opposite poles as their rivalry intensifies. Investors should consider gaining exposure to both spheres.

results.title: Looking for regulatory alignment in insurance
results.thumbnailCaption: Trucks lined up in parking spaces
results.topLine: 360 insurance company executives in 25 different global markets discuss regulatory response insurance. Read more.

cards.takeaway:
As part of our ongoing series based on the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report, 360 senior insurance company executives across 25 markets have shared their experiences and forecasts regarding the global insurance landscape with BlackRock. 

Here's how they answered the question: Following the crisis, what do you believe the regulatory response should be? The following is how their answers break down.

cards.title: Improve alignment of capital treatment with underlying asset risk
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Update accounting rules to align them better to long-term holdings
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Regulatory capital requirements should be more flexible
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Transparency should be improved in the insurance industry
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Liquidity requirements should be reviewed in the insurance industry
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.title: Too early in this current crisis to tell
cards.subtitle: Orange indicates agree; yellow indicates disagree with this regulatory response
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020

cards.takeaway: As insurers have to overhaul their businesses, they look for a helping hand from regulators through improved alignment between capital treatment and the underlying risks of the assets. This chimes with concern about asset price volatility, which is cited as the most important market risk later in the report. A similar number would also like accounting rules to be aligned more closely to long-term holdings.

results.title: Embracing digital transformation in insurance
results.thumbnailCaption: A man and a VR experience
results.topLine: 360 executives in 25 different global markets respond to our questions about digital transformation in the insurance industry.

cards.takeaway: The industry has witnessed significant digital innovation fueled by FinTech investments and InsurTech start-ups. Digital transformation is now becoming a critical component for business continuity and operational resilience, rather than a discretionary spend to gain competitive advantage.

cards.title: Chief Investment Officer, Phoenix Group
cards.quote: Insurers need resilience in terms of their balance sheet and workforce, but also their operational framework. The technology spend for improving the resilience of the operating framework is now an essential priority.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.headline: Granular, real-time portfolio analyses has become critical
cards.body: HCSC is a case in point, as Eric Nilles explains: â€œAs Aladdin users we find that having the ability to run scenario analysis on various levels of the portfolio has been very productive in communicating the risk of the portfolio to senior management even if we did not shock the portfolio exactly as what played out in real markets during COVID.â€
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.body: Paradoxically, the human element is perhaps the hardest aspect of the digital transformation as insurers need to cater for a range of policyholders.

cards.title: CIO, Dai-ichi Life
cards.quote: (Going digital) has proven difficult as our largely older client base still prefers direct meetings. However, without accelerating digitalisation, we will not be able to access clients in the future.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.body: With this challenge outlined, Pascal Christory stresses that â€œAXA wants to offer a multichannel experience as we believe human contact will remain an important component of our distribution model.â€

cards.takeaway: Insurers see a critical role for technology and are ready to embrace the full potential of digital transformation, but remain alert to the differing needs of their client base.

results.title: Reputation of the insurance industry
results.topLine: 360 senior executives in 25 different global markets respond to our questions about the reputation of the insurance industry.

cards.takeaway:
As part of our ongoing series based on the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report, 360 senior insurance company executives across 25 markets have shared their experiences and forecasts regarding the global insurance landscape with BlackRock. 

Here's how they responded to the question: What concerns do you have for the long-term reputation of the insurance industry post-COVID? What follows is how their answers break down.

cards.label: Some concerns
cards.description: Percentage of respondents who believe it will be important to demonstrate that the insurance industry is relevant to its clients.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.label: No material concerns
cards.description: Percentage of respondents who believe the insurance industry has broadly met its obligations and consumers will continue to buy insurance as an operational necessity.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.label: Significant concerns
cards.description: Percentage of respondents who believe that typical insurance buyers may now rethink the role of insurance from both a protection and savings investment perspective.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.headline: Real resilience
cards.body: Ultimately though, the industry remains optimistic it can handle the challenge with the right engagement. As Swiss Reâ€™s CIO Guido FÃ¼rer underscores: â€œI am convinced that the risk capacity and expertise from re/insurers is needed more than ever to help strengthen societal resilience â€“ after all, our industryâ€™s fundamental value proposition is to absorb shocks."
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.title: Group Chief Investment Officer, AXA
cards.quote:
The industry overall has shown resilience and provided appropriate solutions to its clients but its reputation has suffered because of its inability to cover pandemic risks; solving that challenge is, however,
neither simple, obvious or immediate.
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

cards.takeaway: The industry believes it can rise to the challenge, but creating adequate pandemic cover will require a collective effort. Swiss Reâ€™s FÃ¼rer stresses the industry is already actively engaging with governments â€œto discuss public-private partnerships that enable â€˜pandemic-triggeredâ€™ risk sharing.â€ Pascal Christory of AXA concurs that the industry alone cannot solve this, noting that any solution â€œwill involve some mutualisation process and public support.â€
cards.source: BlackRock Global Insurance Survey, June-July 2020.

results.title: Prolonged low rates in insurance
results.topLine: 360 insurance company executives in 25 different global markets discuss repositioning for prolonged low rates. Read more.

cards.takeaway:
As part of our ongoing series based on the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report, 360 senior insurance company executives across 25 markets have shared their experiences and forecasts regarding the global insurance landscape with BlackRock. 

Here's how they answered the question: What steps have you taken in the past 12 months to position for a prolonged period of low interest rates? The following is how their responses break down.

cards.description: of insurers who responded said they improved coordination between investment and product teams to be more responsive to market changes.
said they expanded investment opportunity guidelines in response to competitive pricing pressures.
of insurers we spoke with said they introduced new products designed to be more attractive in a lower interest rate regime.
indicated they eliminated legacy products that are less profitable in the current environment.
of survey respondents said they reduced guarantee rates on existing products to position for a prolonged period of low interest rates.
of the insurers we reached out to had accepted lower spreads in an effort to gain market share.

cards.headline: Dealing with low rates across virtually all major markets
cards.body: While in past years, low rates have translated into lower guarantee levels, the global health emergency has thrown into question the viability of even principal-only guarantees as insurers have to rethink their internal risk-taking capacity given negative or barely positive developed market yields and a sudden, marked decline in regulatory solvency ratios.

cards.title: Head of Strategic Implementation at Zurich
cards.quote: The longer-term concern has to be how the industry and governments respond to the lifetime savings/retirement needs of an ageing society, which is severely challenged by a near/at/below 0% rates backdrop.

cards.takeaway: In this environment, insurers believe they will need to ensure better coordination between investment and product teams to respond proactively to market changes with expanded investment opportunity guidelines and a focus on new products that are better suited to a low rate environment. In practice, insurers will need to revisit how they construct underlying portfolios to ensure products can meet specific outcomes.

results.title: Technology in the new normal for insurance
results.topLine: 360 insurance executives in 25 different global markets respond to our questions about technology in the new normal for insurance.

cards.takeaway: The COVID pandemic has impacted insurersâ€™ revenues and profits, changed the behaviors of their customers, and underscored the need to further embed technology â€“ the digital â€˜first responderâ€™ â€“ across organizations, making it a non-discretionary requirement for operational resilience.

cards.headline: How our reliance on technology is changing
cards.body: As many insurers adapt to this new environment, their reliance on advanced tools to manage, measure and analyze portfolios will be greater. â€˜Front-to-backâ€™ technology solutions that provide speed of execution, modularization and inter-operability are becoming a critical part of the portfolio and risk management workflow. There are four areas where we see the need for particular focus.

cards.label: Strategic asset allocation
cards.description: Portfolio analysis needs to incorporate public and private markets exposures and complex liability profiles, combined with jurisdiction-specific solvency requirements across multiple scenarios.

cards.label: Risk budgeting
cards.description: This process is now taking center stage as company-specific budgets can be calculated through an accounting lens, a mark-to-market lens, a regulatory capital lens, or any combination thereof.

cards.label: Climate analytics and ESG
cards.description: With ESG and climate risk management taking on greater prominence, traditional measures of risk and performance such as duration and convexity have to be combined with climate analytics and ESG measures, as insurers proactively integrate them into their underwriting and investing practices.

cards.label: New accounting guidelines
cards.description: With the requirement to reserve for future expected losses, a robust and reliable platform to project losses across asset classes and assess overall balance sheet volatility is a â€˜need-to-haveâ€™ capability.

cards.takeaway: All of this must be underpinned by operational process efficiency and real-time, dynamic reporting that allows teams to evaluate the impact of their decisions. Hence, for insurers, it is increasingly vital to have access to a unified technology platform that offers the aforementioned capabilities.

results.title: What drives insurersâ€™ robust risk appetite
results.topLine: Is an increase in risk appetite investor preference or necessity?

cards.takeaway:
The BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report reflects survey responses of 360 senior executives in 25 markets representing total assets under management of more than US$24tn. In this story, insurers responded to questions about risk appetite.

As we saw in our previous story, insurers risk appetite is remarkably robust, at levels similar to what we last saw in 2016 and 2018, suggesting the pandemic has not greatly affected risk appetite. The other, and hidden side of the coin, relates to the reset in volatility expectations during the market shock.

cards.body: Value-at-risk portfolio limits that had been suitable to the 2016-2018 period, became outdated in the face of the sudden and generalized increase in volatility, often forcing insurers to accept a higher level of risk in previously more stable asset classes.

cards.title: Group Chief Investment Officer, AIA Group
cards.quote: Market circumstances and falling rates have in the short term constrained willingness to increase exposure to risk assets, but as we move further through and beyond the COVID crisis, a reassessment of risk premia will help insurers reconsider greater exposures to risk assets in the context of lower rates.

cards.body: These altered volatility expectations, while more subdued than at the height of the March/April turmoil, persist today despite a strong S&P rebound and accommodative fiscal and central bank policy actions. These changes in risk appetite appear also to impact asset allocation, with a lower acceptance of credit and illiquidity risk and a higher propensity towards cash, as further described in this report.

cards.takeaway: Sanjay Chawla of FM Global believes such repositioning makes sense: â€œWith the Fed support providing a backstop and momentum to risk assets, we have taken this opportunity to reduce our risk profile given continued economic uncertainty." On balance, insurers appear, however, willing to look through the crisis and explore opportunities given that, as one large European insurer notes, â€œIt is part of the business to keep moving aheadâ€.

results.title: The evolving distribution landscape in insurance
results.topLine: 360 insurance company executives in 25 different global markets discuss changes on the insurance industryâ€™s horizon. Read more.

cards.takeaway: As part of our ongoing series - the BlackRock 2020 Global Insurance Report - we spoke with Ian Haycock, Chief Data Officer at Swiss Re and Pravina Ladva, Life Capital Chief Technology and Operations Officer and Group Digital Transformation at Swiss Re about their perspectives on the evolving digital landscape in insurance. The following is a series of questions we asked and their respective responses.

cards.headline: What major changes are on the insurance industryâ€™s horizon?
cards.body: The pandemic is clearly accelerating the shift to digital across the entire industry. We believe this represents an important opportunity to upgrade distribution models and engage more closely with policyholders. The industry has been talking for a long time about the need to tackle the inherent inefficiencies of the current model, but it has now become a real business priority.

cards.headline: Does this mean a more end-consumer focused industry?
cards.body: The digital shift is driven by consumers who are used to the convenience of online shopping. The pace of change may be slower for life and health insurance products, but the trend is no less real. Addressing these changes demands not just technological investment, but a real understanding of rapidly evolving client needs and how to reflect these across the lifecycle of the products.

cards.headline: What role is there for tech specialists?
cards.body: We think there is opportunity to forge broad coalitions between insurers and insurance tech companies but also other relevant organizations such as equipment manufacturers. Provided they are focused on the right parts of the value chain, such broader partnerships could unlock significant value. It also creates new opportunities for meeting currently unmet demands.

cards.headline: Do these trends apply universally?
cards.body: Successful digital distribution models will incorporate regional differences and consumer preferences. These include diverging regulatory requirements and products, but also different attitudes to technology. Asia and many developing markets, for instance, have gone from face to-face straight to mobile technology, while in Europe brokers continue to play a key role.

cards.headline: How do you address privacy and data concerns?
cards.body:
User comfort with the way data are handled is an important factor in the rate of digital adoption.
Customers are more willing to share their data when they have transparency on how their data
are used and obtain added value in exchange. We think it will be increasingly important to provide
that data-generated value. Naturally, we can also expect more regulatory scrutiny.

cards.headline: Who will be the winners?
cards.body:
Technology is often only seen through the lens of disruption, but implementing a digital
distribution model at large scale requires significant operational experience and resource.
Consumers also want a relationship of trust, which favors companies with a strong brand.

cards.takeaway:
There are three essential considerations insurers need to get right in the evolving distribution landscape. First, define the consumer of your products and put their specific needs at the heart of your model.
Second, value exchange around data â€“ find ways of giving back data to the consumer and add value beyond providing a policy. And last, think through the full lifecycle of the product.

results.title: Macro view: labor participation
results.topLine: As we track the economic restart, we monitor the share of permanent job losses and labor participation rates. Read more.

cards.takeaway: The successful and timely deployment of vaccines will be the key driver of the activity restart in 2021, in our view. Once overall economic activity returns to pre-Covid levels - currently expected by consensus to happen by the end of 2021 - the market focus will likely shift to if and when activity will return to the pre-pandemic trend. Labor market participation is a key indicator we monitor to assess the progress of the restart.

cards.body: The speed with which activity returns to trend crucially depends on whether there is any substantial scarring of potential growth, in our view. Clarity on vaccines should anchor long-term expectations, limiting the extent of scarring and justifying further policy support.

cards.title: Decline in labor participation
cards.subtitle: Labor participation, latest vs Q4 2019
cards.imageCaption: Chart: labor participation rates in key economies
cards.source:
BlackRock Investment Institute, with data from INE, ISTAT, FSO, INSEE, ONS, BLS and Haver,
December 2020. Notes: The chart shows the change in labor participation for the respective country. The latest data is as of Q3 2020 for countries except the U.S. The latest U.S. data point is the November Employment Situation report.

cards.takeaway: The pandemic has accelerated sectoral and distributional shifts. For example, contact-intense services sectors that employ a large number of low skilled workers have taken a major hit. An important signpost we will monitor as we track the economic restart: the share of permanent job losses and labor participation rates.

results.title: Three investing lessons from 2020
results.topLine: We share three key investing lessons from 2020. Read more.

cards.takeaway: 2020 was an extraordinary year for financial markets. The initial Covid shock triggered a massive selloff, followed by a risk rally that extended to the year end. We drew three key lessons from navigating markets. First and foremost, the nature of the Covid shock and the policy revolution triggered by the pandemic were core to the performance of risk assets and our overall asset views.

cards.headline: The nature of the shock
cards.body: Early in the crisis we assessed the ultimate cumulative economic losses - what matters most for financial markets - would likely prove to be a fraction of those seen in the wake of the 2008 global financial crisis. We saw the Covid shock as more akin to a large-scale natural disaster that would be followed by a swift economic restart - if policy support could provide a bridge.

cards.headline: The policy revolution
cards.body:
We saw that response as an opportune time to raise our strategic allocation to equities. On a tactical horizon we upgraded credit and increased our preference for quality assets - and held our moderate pro-risk stance over the rest of 2020. The ongoing fiscal and monetary policy support in 2021 will help
prevent economic scarring as Covid vaccines create a bridge to a post-pandemic economy, in our view.

cards.title: Chart of the week
cards.subtitle: Estimated fiscal and monetary support in key economies, 2020 and 2021
cards.imageCaption: Chart: Estimated fiscal and monetary support in key economies
cards.source: BlackRock Investment Institute, with data from Haver Analytics, December 2020. Notes: The orange bars show estimates of the discretionary fiscal measures in 2020 and 2021 in response to the pandemic, based on proprietary and broker research. The green bars show the estimated impulse of monetary growth in China measured via total social financing. The purple bars show the direct central bank support via programs such as the euro areaâ€™s Targeted Longer-Term Refinancing Operations. The yellow bars show central bank purchases of sovereign debt. For the U.S. we assume the Federal Reserve purchases an additional $80 billion of U.S. government debt per month through 2021, in line with its recent policy announcement. For the euro area we include purchases under the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Program, and the additional 120 billion-euro purchases announced under the Asset Purchase Program. Bars of darker shades represent 2020, and those of lighter shades 2021.

cards.headline: A key consequence of the policy revolution
cards.body: The policy revolution has created the potential for a more muted response of nominal yields to higher inflation. We expect nominal yields to be capped by central banks as they have signaled they will be more willing to let economies run hot with above target inflation. The result: stronger growth and declining real (inflation adjusted) yields.

cards.headline: Long-term structural trends as drivers of asset performance
cards.body: The pandemic has reinforced an increased focus on sustainability and the dominance of e-commerce at the expense of traditional retail. Tech exposures with long-term structural tailwinds have continued to outperform. This helps inform our barbell approach to risk assets over the next 6-12 months: quality assets such as tech and healthcare stocks on one end, and selected cyclical exposures on the other.

Quality assets with strong balance sheets and cash flows also offer resilience against potential bumps on the road to a full activity restart, in our view. We maintain our overweight in the quality style factor and see traditional â€œvalueâ€ sectors facing structural challenges that have been exacerbated by the pandemic, which could limit their upside even with a rapid restart.

cards.headline: Selective cyclicality
cards.body: At mid-year we closed our overweight in U.S. and Asia ex-Japan equities, and upgraded European equities to overweight. These calls turned out to be less successful than some of our other views, such as overweights in high yield credit and the quality style factor. Weâ€™ve since turned neutral on emerging market (EM) debt, and positive on EM equities.

cards.takeaway:
Our directional risk views - driven by the nature of the Covid shock and the policy revolution - were critical
in navigating turbulent market conditions last year. A key takeaway is how swiftly macro policies can evolve and the lasting impact this can have on market dynamics. The policy revolution that started in 2020 is still a key driver of our investment views for this year.

results.title: Could inflation expectations lose their anchor?
results.topLine: Could central banks lose grip of inflation expectations relative to their target levels? Read on.

cards.takeaway: A risk  exists around the loss of the nominal anchor â€” central banks losing grip of inflation expectations relative to their target levels without proper policy guardrails and a clear exit strategy from current stimulus measures. This is not about rampant inflation that could come with unprecedented central bank balance sheet expansion, the fear articulated by some commentators during the GFC and never materialized.

cards.headline: A policy revolution
cards.body: The joint fiscal monetary coordination in response to the Covid-19 shock is nothing short of a policy revolution. The coordination between monetary and fiscal policy is a fait accompli. The implicit, if not explicit, move toward yield curve control targeting government bond yields at low levels is motivated by a desire to avoid a sudden surge in yields during this unprecedented rise in peacetime debt.

Central banks can justify these actions within their current inflation objectives, especially in the absence of upside inflation surprises over the past decade. After more than 30 years, well-anchored inflation expectations are increasingly taken as a market fundamental. Yet in the past it was precisely when anchored inflation expectations were taken for granted that they became unanchored as happened in the 1960s and 1970s.

cards.title: Losing grip on inflation expectations
cards.subtitle: U.S. Phillips curve, 1958-1971
cards.imageCaption: The chart plots the cross of the annual change in the core Consumer Price Index (CPI) against the unemployment rate â€” the Phillips curve.
cards.source: BlackRock Investment Institute and U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, with data from Refinitiv Datastream . Notes: The chart plots the cross of the annual change in the core Consumer Price Index (CPI) against the unemployment rate â€” the Phillips curve.

cards.body: In the 1960s, with inflation assumed to be anchored and unresponsive to a tight labour market, prioritizing full employment became the political consensus. But as this political consensus became clear, inflation expectations started to drift higher, driving inflation. And a significant increase in the cost of production the oil price shocks of the early 1970s added fuel to this inflationary fire.

The painful lesson from this episode: even if inflation appears under control, guardrails are essential to maintain the credibility of the inflation anchor and avoid the political pressures to create an inflationary bias.

The problem may arise when central banks succeed in pushing inflation above target. Without a clear framework, central banks could now find it more difficult to lean against higher inflation. The blurring of fiscal and monetary policy means the decision to start tightening monetary policy will be more politicized.

The underlying inflation dynamics at play, combined with perceived constraints on central banks to raise interest rates in an environment of rising and elevated debt, could raise doubts about the credibility
of inflation targets. Anchoring inflation expectations is about confidence in the central bank.

cards.takeaway: Financial markets react more quickly to changes in future macro behavior than the public. Once higher inflation appears, itâ€™s likely going to be too late markets may have already moved to price in higher inflation expectations. Current breakeven inflation rates suggest this has not happened yet, opening a window of opportunity for long-term investors relative to our inflation expectations.

results.title: Evolution in private equity
results.topLine: Discover the four trends we see in the decade ahead for private equity.

cards.takeaway: In the next decade, we see the private equity industry evolving further along with the four following trends.

cards.label: Democratization of access
cards.description: Recent regulatory approvals in the United States have paved the way for the inclusion of private equity into investors 401(k) accounts.^1
cards.source: 1. Ropes Gray LLP What the DOL Guidance Means for Private Equity and Other Alternative Investments in 401(K) Plans Webcast 2020

cards.body: The recent approval of including private equity in 401 (K) plans by the U.S. Department of Labor provides a number of future implications on the industry as a whole. Private equity solution providers will play a large role, adding an additional layer of fiduciary responsibility to the existing 401(K) sponsor.

The secondary market will have an active role given the desire to front load portfolios with seasoned investments, in addition to the need to re-allocate portfolios on a semi regular basis. Given the total 401(K) market represents approximately $6T of assets, with half of that in target date funds, the total market opportunity is roughly 450 b assuming a 15 allocation to private equity.^1
cards.source: 1. Ropes Gray LLP What the DOL Guidance Means for Private Equity and Other Alternative Investments in 401(K) Plans Webcast 2020

cards.label: Impact of technology
cards.description: Advancements in artificial intelligence and data science have reached the private equity industry and offer sophisticated players a unique advantage over competitors.

cards.body: Emerging technologies and data science techniques have swept across public equities given the vast amount of data publicly available. The private equity industry has largely been left in the dust given its opaque nature, however, recent improvements in natural language processing and other techniques have opened the door to a world of analytical capabilities. Utilizing a variety of alternative data sets enables investors to provide differentiated insights into companies with traditionally limited data available.

cards.label: ESG/Impact investing
cards.description: GPs from across the globe have begun fundraising a variety of sustainable focused strategies. A focus on UN SDG-related themes can provide both financial returns and positive outcomes to society and environment. Attractive themes in the impact investing space include healthcare, financial inclusion, climate, resources and education.

cards.label: Integrated equities
cards.description: Shifts in investor attitudes will drive advancements such as transparency, reporting and analytics. Additionally, investors increasingly see their private and public equity allocation as one integrated equity investment. This will pose important constraints and drive advancements in transparency, reporting and analytics for the private equity industry.

themes: A bigger role for private markets
